Thus have I heard:
Once, the World-Honored One was in the city of Kuru, traveling and teaching, gradually reaching the village of DvÄravatÄ«, staying there with a large assembly of bhiká¹£us.

This great Å›ramaá¹‡a Gautama!

He abandoned his royal status, left home to pursue the path, and has now fulfilled his goal, becoming renowned everywhere. He is the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the One Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, the Well-Gone One, the Knower of the World, the Unsurpassed One, the Tamer of Men, the Teacher of Gods and Men, the Buddha, the World-Honored One.

In the realms of devas, mÄras, BrahmÄ, Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, humans, non-humans, and so forth, he attained perfect enlightenment through his own vows, and with a mind of great compassion, he expounded the true Dharma, which is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with profound and far-reaching meaning, pure and unadulterated, complete with the characteristics of pure conduct.
In this way, he is most honored and supreme. If we see him, we will all gain good benefits. Therefore, we should go to where the Buddha is to pay homage and praise him.
Having discussed this, they all went to the Buddha's assembly.

When they arrived where the Buddha was, some paid homage to the Buddha, some simply joined their palms, and some praised him in various ways. After the assembly had paid homage and praised him like this, they each sat to one side.
At that time, the World-Honored One expounded the Dharma for the assembly, causing their minds to rejoice and giving rise to the great aspiration for enlightenment.

At that time, the brÄhmans and great elders, having listened to and received the Dharma, were all delighted and gave rise to the great aspiration. They immediately rose from their seats, joined their palms in respect towards the Buddha, praised him in various ways, made obeisance to the Buddha, and withdrew.
At that time, there was a great elder in the assembly named Protector of the Nation. Out of longing for the Buddha, he did not leave the Dharma assembly. He had this thought:
The Dharma I have heard is reliable and will surely lead to perfect enlightenment.
If I remain in the household life, I will forever be mired in saá¹ƒsÄra.

The Buddha is difficult to encounter. With faith, I will leave the household life in search of liberation. Therefore, I will now leave behind all heedlessness and give rise to great diligence. Relying on the Buddha, I will leave the household life and purely cultivate the holy life. I will aspire to shave my beard and hair and wear the Dharma robes.

At that time, having had this thought, the elder Protector of the Nation immediately rose from his seat, went before the Buddha, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, joined his palms in respect towards the Buddha, and said to the Buddha:

I have heard the true Dharma from the World-Honored One, become weary of the suffering of cyclic existence, and given rise to a mind of faith and joy. Therefore, I now seek to go forth under the Buddha.
May the World-Honored One accept me.
The Buddha said to RajanÄ«:
Do your parents allow you to go forth with faith?
RajanÄ« replied:
No, they do not.
World-Honored One!
My parents do not allow it.
The Buddha said to RajanÄ«:
If your parents do not allow it, you cannot go forth.
RajanÄ« further said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Although my parents have not yet allowed it, I will certainly request them to grant permission.
The Buddha told RajanÄ«:
As you wish, now is the right time.
At that time, the elder RajanÄ« received the Buddha's instructions, bowed to the Buddha and withdrew, returned to his home and said to his parents:
Parents, with compassionate thoughts, please listen to my words.
I heard the Buddha speak the Dharma in the Buddha's assembly, and I understood all the Dharma I heard. I then gave rise to right faith and wished to leave the household life.
I only wish that my parents will allow me to do so.
At that time, the parents told Guhyaraja:ğŸ”½What benefits do you seek in wanting to leave the household life?
What have you gained that you seek to leave the household life?
If you leave the household life, will you not live by begging for alms?

You should know that we now have immeasurable wealth and treasures. You should just stay at home, give away your wealth to make merit, and enjoy the pleasures of life. Why do you need to leave the household life?
In this way, the parents used kind words to persuade him.
At that time, Guhyaraja again said:
Parents, you should remember that I am disgusted with the cycle of rebirth, and I abandon worldly glory, aspiring to leave the household life. I only wish that you will allow me.
In this way, Guhyaraja made his request again and again.
At that time, the parents again said to him:
The resolve you have cherished and sought to leave the household life, is it not to live by begging?

My family's storehouses are filled with countless treasures of gold, silver, and precious jewels. Simply stay at home, give away your wealth to make merit, and enjoy the pleasures of wealth. Why must you leave the household life?
In this way, the parents tried to persuade him two or three times.
At that time, Guhyaraja again said:
If my parents do not give their permission, I vow from now on not to eat or drink until my life ends.
Having made this vow, he immediately stopped eating and drinking.
At that time, many acquaintances of Guhyaraja, having heard of this, immediately went together to the parents of the elder Guhyaraja and said to them:
Elderly parents!
We have all heard that your son Guhyaraja loves to leave the household life, and although he has this resolve, you do not give your permission.
We know your son, but his resolve to seek the Way is firm, even though he enjoys wealth and pleasure;
If you do not allow it now, he will suffer grief and will die. You will then experience the suffering of separation from what you love.
Therefore, you should allow him to go forth.
Then the head of the household, seeing that his son's friends and acquaintances were earnestly requesting it, allowed him to go forth.
At that time, many friends and acquaintances of Prince RÄá¹£á¹­rapÄla, having received the word from his father, went to RÄá¹£á¹­rapÄla and said to him together:
RÄá¹£á¹­rapÄla, you should know that now your parents have allowed you to go forth.
At that time, RÄá¹£á¹­rapÄla, having received the word from his parents, was overjoyed. He went to his parents, took leave of them, and left. He returned to where the Buddha was.
Having arrived where the Buddha was, he bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, joined his palms together, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Now my parents have allowed me to go forth.
I pray that the Buddha, out of compassion, will mercifully accept me and make me a bhiká¹£u.
At that time, the World-Honored One said to RÄá¹£á¹­rapÄla:

At that time, the hair and beard of the protector of the country fell off by themselves, he put on the kaá¹£Äya robe, became a bhiká¹£u, cultivated pure conduct, removed that heedlessness, was free from all worries and distress, his mind was naturally disciplined and he realized the purity of the Dharma, his births were ended, his pure conduct was established, his work was done, and he would not undergo any further existences.
At that time, the Venerable Protector of the Country, having attained the destruction of the contaminants, relied on the Buddha for ten summers.
After ten summers, he put on his robe, took his alms bowl, went to where the Buddha was, bowed his head to [the Buddha's] feet, joined his palms together, stood to one side, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I originally lived in the town of Tora, abandoned my relatives, and left the household life out of faith.
I now wish to return to my hometown to be close to my relatives, and await the Buddha's instructions.

At that time, the World-Honored One knew what Venerable Guardian of the Nation had in mind. He also observed that Guardian of the Nation's mind was firm and he wished to benefit widely. Moreover, in the past when he was a layperson, he was always free from desires. Having observed this, he then told him:
Venerable Guardian of the Nation!
Now is the right time, you may do as you wish.

At that time, Venerable Guardian of the Nation accepted the Buddha's instruction, rejoiced and leaped with joy, circumambulated the Buddha three times, bowed his head at the Buddha's feet, took leave of the Buddha and withdrew. He returned to his birthplace and gradually reached his original village.
After spending the night there, at dawn he put on his robes, took his alms bowl, and went begging for food in order. He returned to his original house.
He saw a woman outside the door of the house, holding a full vessel of food and about to throw it away. Venerable Guardian of the Nation saw this and told the woman:
You have no shame! Do not throw away the food!
How about giving it to me and putting it in my bowl? You will then gain benefits.
At that time, the woman heard the Venerable One's words and her heart was filled with respect. She immediately offered the food and placed it in the bowl.
The Venerable One accepted it and went to the foot of a large tree, where he arranged his seat and was about to eat.
At that time, the woman thought like this:
This is my master's son, the Venerable Protector of the Nation.
At that time, after the woman had this thought, she went to the master of the elder and said to the elder:
Just outside the gate, I saw the elder's son holding a bowl to beg for food. He went to the foot of a large tree, arranged his seat, and was about to eat.
At that time, the master of the elder, upon hearing this, was greatly delighted and immediately asked the woman:
Is it true as you have said?
The woman replied:
It is true.
At that time, the elder quickly left his house and went to the foot of the large tree. Having arrived there, he truly saw Protector of the Nation there, about to eat. He immediately said:
My son, Protector of the Nation!
Abandoning his original home, he wanders outside as a guest. In this way, he passes through and arrives at a village, but does not enter his original house. What is the meaning of this?
At that time, Huguo replied to his father, saying:
The rules of our Å›ramaá¹‡as are like this. Entering others' houses is not suitable for me.
At that time, the head of the household supported Huguo and brought him back to his original home. Having arrived at the house, he spread out a seat and told him to sit.
At that time, Huguo's mother came before her son. With a heart of deep affection, she repeatedly consoled him and said to Huguo:
Why is it, my son, that you have left home with a firm intention?
What benefits have you gained from leaving home?
What have you attained?
It is only to seek alms and sustain your life. Therefore, you should not leave home again now. Give up wealth to make merit and enjoy the wealth of the rich.
At that time, the kind mother devised various means to keep her son and not let them part. She piled up gold, silver, and various precious treasures in front of the Venerable One and said to her son:
My son, you should know that I have such vast wealth and treasures. I now give them to you, let alone the immeasurable wealth of your father. For this reason, how can you leave home?
You should stay at home now, give away your wealth to make merit, and enjoy all the riches and pleasures.
At that time, the Venerable One said to his mother:
Kind mother, please remember that these many gold, silver, and various treasures are the root of all faults.
Having said this, he had them carried by cart and carried on his back and abandoned them in the river. He then said to his mother:

Loving mother, remember this. These treasures are due to attachment. Because of this, various faults arise, leading to difficulties such as those caused by water, fire, kings, thieves, and evil children. Such various sufferings of destruction arise. Know that the cause of this suffering does not come from your mother.
At that time, the mother of the protector of the country, unable to let go of her son, devised another plan and thought like this:
The wife of the son when he was at home should be adorned with jewels and treasures, and come to where the protector of the country is, to please his mind.
Having thought like this, she went to his wife and said to her:

The treasures, precious jewels, necklaces, and adornments that your husband, the son of the householder, loved when he was at home, you should now adorn yourself with and go to where the protector of the country is, to please his mind.

At that time, the wife of the protector of the country, having received the order, immediately adorned herself with various treasures and jewels, went to where the protector of the country was, and said to him:
Son of the householder!
What do you think?
Do you uphold the pure precepts in order to seek celestial maidens?
The country protector said:
No, elder sister!
I uphold the pure precepts in order to seek the fruits of the path;
What you say is not so.
At that time, when the country protector's wife heard the call of elder sister, she immediately changed her expression, feeling ashamed and retreated.
At that time, the Venerable Country Protector had this thought:
It is time for the meal.
He then said to his father:
Elder!
What drinks and food do you have to offer me?
At that time, the parents personally took the finest delicacies and various foods to offer to the Venerable One.

At that time, after the Venerable One had finished his meal, washed his bowl, put away his robe, arranged his seat and sat down, he expounded the true Dharma for his parents, causing them to give rise to a joyful mind and the intention for the path. He then manifested his spiritual powers, remaining in the sky and spoke this verse:
Contemplate this painted form, adorned with various treasures,
The foolish and deluded cling to it, while the wise always keep their distance.
Greed is like a rope, able to bind the world,
The foolish are confused by it, while the wise always keep their distance.
At that time, after the Venerable One had spoken this gÄthÄ, he descended from the sky and returned to the foot of the great tree to peacefully abide.
At that time, there was a king named KÅ«ru who was traveling outside and was about to pass by the side of the Dolu village. The attendants reported:
Great King!
You should know that in this village there is an elder's son named Guotan, with a vast retinue and immeasurable wealth and treasures, who has renounced the householder's life.
When the king heard this, he immediately asked the villagers:
You people, is it true that in this place there is an elder's son named Guotan who has abandoned his relatives and gone forth?
The people of the village then reported to the king, saying:
Great King!
You should know that this matter is indeed so.
The Venerable Guardian of the Nation is always practicing pure conduct under a large tree in our village, and we people are close to him and make offerings.
Having heard the report, the king went to that place in the village and to the tree under which the Venerable One was staying.

At that time, the Venerable One observed from afar the approaching life force and saw that King KÅ«ru was rushing to where he was. He immediately rose from his seat and advanced to where the king was, and said these words:
Great King!
Welcome!
This realm is under the rule of the king. I now invite the Great King to go to the tree under which I am sitting.
At that time, the king replied:
Guardian of the Nation!
My intention is just so. I wish to go to where you are and sit on your seat.
The Guardian of the Nation said again:
Since the king's intention is like this, I therefore invite the king.
At that time, the king accompanied the Venerable One to the foot of a large tree and sat down.
Then, the great king said to Guogu:
There are four kinds of dharmas, by which these four dharmas seek to leave the household life.
The four dharmas are:
First, knowing relatives, second, knowing wealth and nobility, third, knowing illness, and fourth, knowing old age. These are the four dharmas.
How does one know relatives?
It means if a person's relatives are vast and suddenly scattered, this person thinks:
'My relatives, friends, and acquaintances have all scattered away, and I am alone. I should leave the household life.'
This person understands that because there are no relatives, he seeks to leave the household life.
Now, you, Guogu!
Your relatives are vast and you are not alone. You cannot understand why you should leave the household life?
Moreover, what is meant by knowing wealth and nobility?

It means that if there were a person who previously had wealth and treasures and was very rich, but later exhausted them all and poverty arose accordingly, because of poverty he would think like this:
Now, because of poverty, he thinks like this:
'Now, because of the suffering of poverty, I should go forth.'
This person understands that because of poverty he seeks to go forth.
Now, you, Guardian of the Nation!
Your wealth is immeasurable and you are not poor. You cannot understand why one would go forth.
Moreover, what is meant by knowing the suffering of illness?
It means that if there were a person who had been sick for a long time and had no one to save or cure him, he would think like this:
'This illness of mine is deeply painful. Therefore, I should now seek to go forth.'
This person understands that because of the suffering of illness he seeks to go forth.
Now, you, Guardian of the Nation!
You have few illnesses and few afflictions, and are also without the suffering of worry. You cannot understand why one would go forth.
Moreover, what is meant by knowing old age and decrepitude?
It means if there is a person who is old and decrepit, they may think like this:
'I am now old and decrepit, unable to enjoy any wealth or pleasures, therefore I will now seek to go forth.'
This person knows that being old and decrepit is unsuitable and seeks to go forth.
Now, you, Guardian of the Nation!
In the prime of youth, not yet experiencing any pleasures, you cannot understand why one would go forth.
Guardian of the Nation, you should understand that these four dharmas are what lead one to go forth.
I will now ask Guardian of the Nation further, what have you seen or heard that leads you to go forth?
At that time, the Venerable One replied to the king, saying:
Great King!
You should know that there are four kinds of dharmas that lead one to seek to go forth.
What are the four?
They are old age, sickness, desire, and death.
Degeneration and decay over time is called old age, illness and suffering without cure is called sickness, insatiable desire is called desire, abandoning all objects is called death.

The World-Honored One has thoroughly understood and seen these four dharmas. I have also personally seen and heard from the Buddha. For this reason, I have given rise to great faith and left the household life.
The king said:
Venerable One!
I still do not understand the brief explanation given earlier. I only wish that the Venerable One would explain it in detail for me, so that I may understand.
At that time, the Venerable One, having heard the king's words, said to the king:
Great King!
Excellent!
I shall explain it as you wish.
The king said:
Venerable One!
What is meant by 'aging is not long-lasting'?
The Venerable One replied:
Great King!
What do you think?
If a person, from the age of twenty or thirty, reaches forty, what will their appearance, physical strength, movements, and behavior be like?
The king said:
Venerable One!

When a person is twenty to forty years old, they have a full set of physical characteristics, strong bodily strength, courageous and vigorous behavior, and in all their undertakings they consider themselves unmatched;
If they reach old age, they become decrepit and incapable, their physical characteristics change, their bodily strength weakens, and their behavior becomes feeble.
The Venerable One said:
As the King has said, this is the aging characteristic that changes the world.
Great King!
You should know that this is the first teaching spoken by our Buddha.

Moreover, the World-Honored Buddha has well understood, well known, and well spoken this teaching. I have also seen and heard it, and with love and aspiration for this true teaching, I have left the household life with faith.
Then the King said:
Venerable Guardian of the Nation!
I too have encountered this true teaching with love and aspiration.
Moreover, the King said:
Venerable Guardian of the Nation!
What is called the characteristic of illness, which is incurable and swift to afflict?
The Venerable One replied:
It is like a person who has great wealth, treasures, and relatives, whose number is immeasurable.
What do you think?
When that person is sick in bed and suffering from various afflictions, can their relatives and attendants take on their suffering and afflictions on their behalf?
The king said:
No, they cannot.
Guotan!
When a person is sick in bed, they alone experience all the suffering, and there is no one to take their place or rescue them.
The Venerable One said:
As the king has said, having no one to take one's place and no one to rescue one is the characteristic of sickness. This is the second teaching spoken by our Buddha.

The World-Honored Buddha has thoroughly understood, thoroughly known, and thoroughly taught this teaching. I have also seen and heard it. I have left the household life with faith and aspiration for this true Dharma.
At that time, the king said:
Venerable Guotan!
I too have encountered this joyous Dharma and aspire to it with love and determination.
The king asked again:
Venerable One!
How is it that insatiable desire is called love?
The Venerable One replied:
Great King!
What do you think?
The king is a wealthy one, and the people living in the cities and towns of the kingdom, up to the southeast, northwest, and all under the king's rule, are all greatly wealthy.
The king said to the Venerable One:
It is so, it is so!
The Venerable One said again:
Great King, the cities and villages under your rule are so wealthy, suppose someone comes by sea and says to the Great King:
'I have seen a certain country, the cities and towns are vast, the people are prosperous, with rare treasures such as gold and silver, elephants, horses, and soldiers, their number is immeasurable.'
Great King!
Having heard this, what do you think?
The king said:
Venerable One!
If I hear of this matter, if I do not go myself, I will immediately send an envoy to conquer them, and bring back precious treasures and goods to increase my treasury.
At that time, the Venerable One said:
Great King!
This insatiable is called craving, and this is the third teaching spoken by the Buddha.

Moreover, the World-Honored Buddha has well understood, well known, and well spoken this teaching. I have also seen and heard it, and with love and aspiration for this true teaching, I have left the household life with faith.
At that time, the king said:
Venerable Guardian of the Nation!
I too love and aspire to this joyful encounter with the true teaching.
The king asked again:
Venerable One!
How is it that one abandons all realms and is called dead?
The Venerable One replied:
Great King!
What do you think?
Do I see that a person with great treasures and great wealth, when they leave this realm and are reborn in another realm, can take their treasures with them?
The king said:
No, I do not.ğŸ”½
The Venerable One said again:
Great King!
In this world, abandoning all beloved objects and being born in another world, this is called death. This is the fourth thing that the Buddha has taught.
The Buddha has thoroughly understood and well taught this Dharma. I have also seen and heard it, and with love and aspiration for this true Dharma, I have gone forth with faith.
The king said:
Venerable One!
I too have encountered this joyous true Dharma with love and aspiration.
At that time, the Venerable One again said to the king:
I wish to explain this meaning again. You should listen well.
The king said:
Very good! I joyfully wish to hear it.
At that time, the Venerable One spoke a verse, saying:
I see that in the world, people, out of greed and love, accumulate wealth,
And because of wealth, they encounter difficulties, and their desires increase even more.
The king rules over the country and cities, vast as the edge of the ocean,
Yet he is still not content, and further attacks other countries.
Sentient beings in the world, due to greed and love, perish,
Grieving and crying in sorrow, lamenting how quickly they pass away.
Like a person gathering wealth and treasures, only to be burned by fire,
Sentient beings also follow their karma, receiving the consequences of their actions.
Wealth and abundance do not prolong life, nor do they avoid old age,
Both the wealthy and the poor perish, the noble and the young are impermanent.
Sickness does not discriminate between the brave and the strong, nor does it discriminate between the noble and the young,
All due to greed and love, one cannot escape impermanence.
Like a person who steals, only to harm themselves in return,
Thus, seeing the world, they create various evil causes themselves.
Like a fruit ripe and falling on its own, the destruction of the old and young is the same,
With a joyful mind one creates karma, but suffers and grieves when receiving its consequences.
At that time, foolish people in the world create karma without realizing it,
Or born in another world, due to hatred and love one obtains suffering.
If life ends in the womb, who can save and protect?
Even if one has close friends, when life ends, how can they save?
Desire destroys and binds, producing suffering and increasing fears.
Seeing the illusory dharmas of the world, therefore I have gone forth.
At that time, having heard the Venerable One's verses, King KururÄja joyfully believed and accepted, and further said:
Venerable Guardian of the Nation, you are able to skillfully escape, therefore I now take refuge in the Venerable One.
The Guardian of the Nation said:
Great King!
Do not take refuge in me, I take refuge in the Buddha, the World-Honored One, and in the Dharma and Saá¹…gha, the king should take refuge in them.
The king said:
So it is!
I now take refuge in the Buddha, the Dharma, and the Saá¹…gha, and uphold the precepts of an upÄsaka for as long as I live.
At that time, after the great king made this vow, he paid homage to the Venerable One and returned to the palace.
